channel.title: C++ VS Java
channel.description:
Who do you think is best to use :confused:
I think Java :D C++ is for hardcoding

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

[quote=“Fr33sc4p3, post:14, topic:87917”]Private servers arnt for idoits, just the idoits have ruined them.

Im pretty sure if Moparscape wasnt over run by idoits alot of the people from mitb would of coded up their own server, Proper and wouldnt mind playing around with them.

The private server community has give its self a bad name.[/quote]

We think on the same level. I may just delete this moparscape account, and start anew.

Hey i saw you ruler, on your ownage thing

EDIT: Java can rarely do anything thats not just a convenience(or just ‘fun’) on its own. . .

Read full topic

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @cruel cruel
item.description:
@cruel wrote:

Yeah well… methods/properties are a bit easier to interpret from byte code than machine code.
That’s a pro, but also a big con to many.

They’re both great.
Java is easier, but C++ can serve more purposes. And it’d be for that reason I’d say C++ is best. Although there are many purposes where C++ would struggle, yet Java would succeed.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“pplsuqbawlz, post:17, topic:87917”]I have done alot of work with C++ and C, and it’s pointers are strictly all you need to get full access to any specific part of an allocated sector of memory. Assuming you have an idea of what you’re doing;

learn: Where rawr is an array of char[9]; and the last 4 char’s compose the unsigned int…

if(reinterpret_cast<unsigned int>(rawr + 5) == 133333337) { printf("Pplsuqbawlz 4king rules!"); }

But once again, I reiterate, they are two different worlds, with two completely different atmospheres, stop assuming they can mix.[/quote]
true but you have to know exactly what you are looking for.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

I have done alot of work with C++ and C, and it’s pointers are strictly all you need to get full access to any specific part of an allocated sector of memory. Assuming you have an idea of what you’re doing;

learn: Where rawr is an array of char[9]; and the last 4 char’s compose the unsigned int…

if(reinterpret_cast<unsigned int>(rawr + 5) == 133333337) { printf("Pplsuqbawlz 4king rules!"); }

But once again, I reiterate, they are two different worlds, with two completely different atmospheres, stop assuming they can mix.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“ruler, post:15, topic:87917”][quote author=newbiehacker link=topic=128726.msg1254685#msg1254685 date=1178147802]
c++ doesn’t need reflection for the simple fact that you can have pointers. Also reflection in java is an ugly hack.

Now will people please stop trying to compare them.

c++ is fast, object-orientated and very good if you don’t like cross-platform compatibility and you are comfortable enough with your coding that you can create an application that can efficiently handle its memory consumption.
Java is also fast (not AS fast, but the VM is built for speed and will handle memory much more efficiently than a novice programmer could), it handles its memory itself and can be embedded within browsers. It’s not as easy to have an executable java program (unless it’s in a jar file)

So yeah, stop comparing or I will have to shoot you.
[/quote]
reflection is becoming a main-stay in programming.

Keep in mind i haven’t done alot of work in C++.

How would you take a C++ object and find all of its properties and abilities?

Microsoft’s powershell .NET will being using alot of reflection, C#.[/quote]only because sun did it first

Read full topic

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“newbiehacker, post:10, topic:87917”]c++ doesn’t need reflection for the simple fact that you can have pointers. Also reflection in java is an ugly hack.

Now will people please stop trying to compare them.

c++ is fast, object-orientated and very good if you don’t like cross-platform compatibility and you are comfortable enough with your coding that you can create an application that can efficiently handle its memory consumption.
Java is also fast (not AS fast, but the VM is built for speed and will handle memory much more efficiently than a novice programmer could), it handles its memory itself and can be embedded within browsers. It’s not as easy to have an executable java program (unless it’s in a jar file)

So yeah, stop comparing or I will have to shoot you.[/quote]
reflection is becoming a main-stay in programming.

Keep in mind i haven’t done alot of work in C++.

How would you take a C++ object and find all of its properties and abilities?

Microsoft’s powershell .NET will being using alot of reflection, C#.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

c++ doesn’t need reflection for the simple fact that you can have pointers. Also reflection in java is an ugly hack.

Now will people please stop trying to compare them.

c++ is fast, object-orientated and very good if you don’t like cross-platform compatibility and you are comfortable enough with your coding that you can create an application that can efficiently handle its memory consumption.
Java is also fast (not AS fast, but the VM is built for speed and will handle memory much more efficiently than a novice programmer could), it handles its memory itself and can be embedded within browsers. It’s not as easy to have an executable java program (unless it’s in a jar file)

So yeah, stop comparing or I will have to shoot you.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“regecks`, post:3, topic:87917”]Use a combination:

[code]public class Test {

public static void main(String[] args) {
try {
Runtime.getRuntime().exec(“gcc -o cProg cProg.c”);
Runtime.getRuntime().exec(“cProg.exe”);
} catch(Exception e) ( }
}

}[/code]
And have your C code in cProg.c![/quote]i lold

Read full topic

item.title: C++ VS Java
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

Use a combination:

[code]public class Test {

public static void main(String[] args) {
try {
Runtime.getRuntime().exec(“gcc -o cProg cProg.c”);
Runtime.getRuntime().exec(“cProg.exe”);
} catch(Exception e) ( }
}

}[/code]
And have your C code in cProg.c!
